loans.name: Maria Nicolasa

texts.es:
María tiene 42 años, es conviviente y reside con su familia en casa propia ubicada en el distrito de Paiján, perteneciente a la Región La Libertad, ubicada a 4 horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital del departamento de Lambayeque.  

María se dedica desde hace 10 años a la venta de leche, a sus vecinos y clientela quien por la calidad del producto siempre la escogen.  Para esta actividad posee 6 vacas productoras de leche.  Los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad le permiten cubrir sus gastos personales y los de su familia.

María desea vender mayores volúmenes de leche, es por ello que desea comprar más alimento para su ganado, ya que al estar mejor alimentadas producirán más leche.  Ante ello, María ha creído conveniente obtener un préstamo 1000 nuevos soles a Edpyme Alternativa.
texts.en:
María is 42 years old.  She lives with her partner and family in her own home which is located in Paiján district, in La Libertad province, 4 hours from the city of Chiclayo (the capital of Lambayeque department).

María has been selling milk for 10 years.  She sells to her neighbors and customers who always buy from her because of the good quality of her product.  María has 6 milk-producing cows.  The income that she makes from this business allow her to cover her personal expenses as well as those of her family.

María would like to sell larger volumes of milk and so she would like to buy more feed for her cattle because, if they are better fed, they will produce more milk.  For this reason, María is requesting a loan for 1,000 soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy nutritionally-balanced feed for her cows

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a farmer in Murang'a area of Central Kenya and has been in farming for  30 years. He is married and has six children, four adults and two minors. He currently employs two farmhands and produces milk, tea, and horticultural products for the local market. He also runs a motorcycle transport business for additional income.

Daniel is requesting a loan for 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo, which he will use to install an irrigation system at his farm. He will buy a water pump for 45,000 KES and irrigation pipes with the remaining 15,000 KES. He is focusing on expanding his horticultural products on his farm so that he can export his produce.

The periodic drought is Daniel's main challenge in farming in the area. He notes that Juhudi Kilimo is assisting farmers through the loan provisions.

loans.use: to purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Josef

texts.en:
Josef is 35 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala south region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, of whom one is currently in school. For the past 3 years, Josef has been working hard to manage his small bar, which sells drinks.

To help expand his business, Josef has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drinks for resale, and will help Josef to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Josef hopes that in the future he will be able to construct more rental houses. 

Josef is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Josef who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for resale.

loans.name: Matogoma

texts.fr:
Madame  Matogoma est âgée de 27 ans, elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants, résidant avec son époux à Lafiabougou, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Matogoma après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité de coupe et couture il y a onze ans. Son atelier de couture se trouve au grand marché de Sikasso où elle dispose déjà de 4 machines dont 2 machines de broderie et 2 machines de couture simple. Madame Matogoma est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses services. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle sollicite un deuxième prêt individuel qui lui permettra d’acheter des pièces de rechange pour ses quatre machines et les tissus pour en coudre et ensuite les revendre afin de mieux répondre aux attentes de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Matogoma is 27 years old, married, and the mother of three children.  She lives with her husband in Lafiabougou, a district on the outskirts of Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After having tried many types of work unsuccessfully, Mrs. Matogoma began making clothing eleven years ago. Her sewing workshop is located in the main market of Sikasso where she already owns four sewing machines:  two for embroidering and two for simple sewing. 

Mrs. Matogoma is much in demand for the quality of her services. 

With the goal of better meeting the growing demand of her customers, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from whom she is now requesting a second individual loan which will allow her to buy spare parts for her four machines and fabric for sewing and selling.  This will allow her to better meet the expectations of her ever-growing clientele.  The previous loan was properly repaid. 

She foresees earning a monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA which will mostly be used to increase her working capital, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on her loan.

loans.use: to buy fabric and spare parts for her sewing machines.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 36-year-old, married woman with one child who has completed high school. Her husband, Ashraff, is a tailor who contributes to the provision of the family’s basic needs.  Janet lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her largest monthly expenses are food for her family and the electricity bill. 

Janet has operated a business selling fried potatoes for the past 10 years.  Her potential clients are the local area residents. Janet must deal with the challenge of debtors not paying their debts on time.  She dreams of owning a house in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, Janet wants to purchase additional potato stock and cooking oil for her business.  She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu to access loan opportunities.

loans.use: to purchase more potato stock and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa is a petty trader. She operates a grocery shop in Bereman near Abura. The items in her grocery shop are milk, milo, sugar, soups, different kinds of soft drinks, tinned tomatoes, tinned fish, biscuits, toffees, powdered milk and kenkey. She has been doing this for two years.

Yaa is married to a farmer and has three children. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their home.  

Yaa needs this loan to purchase a variety of grocery items to satisfy her customers. With the new profit, Yaa wishes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase variety of grocery items to satisfy her customers.

loans.name: Huda

texts.en: Huda is a 42-year-old married woman from Jubeiha in Jordan. She has four children and requested a 500 JOD loan to pay for her home improvement expenses. She is planning to install a kitchen and in the future, Huda is planning to buy a gas stove and an oven.

loans.use: to pay for her home improvement expenses.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 45 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Moses has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, soap, rice, flour, posho, detergent, and cooking oil. 

To help expand his business, Moses has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more soap, rice, flour, posho, detergent, and cooking oil and will help Moses to generate greater profits and educate his children. Moses hopes that in the future, he will be able to have more houses for rent. 

Moses is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Moses who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more soap, rice, flour, posho, detergent and cooking oil

loans.name: Efrosinia

texts.en: Efrosinia is originally from the village of Slobozia Mare in the south of Moldova. As a single mother, she has been working in the capital city for the past years to earn money and support her two children who are now in high school. She recently returned to her hometown and opened a small store on the property where she was born. Housed in a movable building, her store is the only one on that side of the village and offers drinks, snacks and necessities to nearby residents. She hopes eventually to expand her business to include a sauna and also to construct a home for her family on the same property. Her philosophy, however, is that careful planning is required and that her business will only grow in a stable fashion with gradual steps. The first of these is to offer more goods to her customers and to provide them a place to relax and consume the drinks and snacks she sells. To this end she would like to construct a small terrace in front of the store and acquire a greater and more varied inventory.

loans.use: Improvement of store and purchase of new inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The money will be invested in improvements to his business premises and in the repair and maintenance of the wheeled equipment he uses to sell propane gas and deliver his products to his clients' homes.

loans.name: Nora Verónica

texts.en:
Nora is a very responsible and hard working women. She is a single mother of a son aged 2. She didn't have the support of her spouse for her son's expenses and has hence had to work arduously.

20 years ago her father started a business manufacturing leather goods, now her brother is in charge of the business and she has partnered with him. Their good work and the quality of the goods they make has allowed them to be in this business for so long.

In order to grow the business and fill large orders she has on hold, Nora needs a loan of $1,200 to buy the supplies necessary to manufacture her products.

She is committing to pay back the loan in 6 to 12 months. You can contribute to the strengthening of this business and the improvement of this family's life. They will be than you.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Nora es una mujer responsable y muy trabajadora, es madre soltera de un pequeño de 2 años de edad, no contó con el apoyo de su pareja para los gastos de su hijo por lo que ha tenido que trabajar arduamente. Hace 20 años su padre inició un negocio en el que elaboraba y vendía productos de piel, ahora su hermano se hace cargo de este negocio y ella se ha asociado con él, el buen trabajo que realizan y la calidad de sus productos les ha concedido permanecer por tanto tiempo en el negocio.

Para hacer crecer su negocio y surtir grandes pedidos que tiene, Nora solicita un préstamo por $ 1,200 dólares que utilizará en la compra de insumos que requiere en la elaboración de sus productos, ella se compromete a regresar esta cantidad en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. Tú puedes contribuir al fortalecimiento de este negocio y a mejorar la vida de esta familia, ellos te lo agradecerán.

loans.use: Purchasing supplies

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph T. is twenty-eight years old and determined to make his life better. A school drop-out, he managed to establish a small grocery wholesale shop in Magburaka town of Sierra Leone. With his innovative business, Joseph has enabled many petty traders, specifically women who have little business capital, to buy items for resale such as tomato paste, onions, and peanuts within the town without traveling to Freetown or faraway villages. Many of the women appreciate his fair, good service that has saved them time and money.

Joseph would like to be able to provide his services to more vendors and therefore is requesting for a loan of $1050. This will enable him to import goods from Guinea which are cheaper than those from Freetown.

Joseph has been a good example to other youth that one can succeed through hard work and self-employment. He was also recently made the Assistant Head of the Traders Union, based his outstanding business and leadership skills.

loans.use: Increase  the inventory of grocery items he sells wholesale

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Mrs. Seang S., 43, lives with her husband (pictured) and children in the Prey Ven Province of Cambodia. She owns a grocery store which earns her $10. She is requesting this loan because she would like to sell a greater variety of products to more effectively meet her client’s needs. Meanwhile, her husband works as a tyre repair man, earning $2.5 a day and her 2 employed children earn $75 a month as truck drivers. Her other 5 children are students.

loans.use: to add more products to her inventory to meet her cients needs

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Sr. Pedro Giménez is 62 years old, married, and has three children. All of his children are grown up and married. Pedro lives in a small house with his wife Maria, who is 58. Maria contributes to the household income by working as a seamstress;  in addition, she works in the family store. The couple is also currently building an addition to their house for their youngest son and his wife. 
In 2001, Pedro opened a small despensa, or convenience store, in addition to working as a construction contractor. His store primarily sells drinks and, due to local demand, has continuously grown over time. Pedro currently cooperates with a wholesale supplier to stock his store.
In addition to running his store, Pedro still works as a contractor. Also Pedro's son Reddy, who lives with his father, is a contractor - they work together every day on a variety of construction projects. During this time, Pedro’s wife Maria attends to the store. 
Whenever times were difficult, Pedro managed to learn new skills in order to support his family. For example, he taught himself how to do electrical work and plumbing, and can therefore now offer a variety of services to his clients. 
Pedro has asked for a loan of US$325 in order to expand the variety of stock in his shop. With the greater variety, he hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, oil, flour, cookies, and other merchandise

loans.name: Sri

texts.en: Sri P. is 30 years old and is the mother of a child aged 12. She sells detergents on credit. Her husband, Usman, is a farmer who earns US$ 2 per day and their two incomes are barely enough to cover their daily needs. Sri has to work hard to help support her family, so she is requesting a loan of US$ 75 to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her little detergent business

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Greetings from Mbeya, Tanzania! Neema S. is 34 years old and is married with four children, ages 7, 11, 13, and 15. She has one other dependent: her nephew. In 2000, Neema established a farm machinery rental business. She now requests a loan of $200 in order to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: to expand her farm machinary rental business

loans.name: Sabur

texts.ru:
Sabur K. has been our successful client since 2004. He is married and has one son. His wife stays at home and helps Sabur's mother with house chores. Sabur has been a businessman for 10 years. Sabur used to sell video cassettes on the streets. Having received his first loan from MicroInvest, he increased the volume of sales and successfully paid back his loan. Next, Sabur saved his money and opened his own store; today he has a wide variety of DVDs and many permanent clients not only among local consumers, but also consumers from outlying regions. Savur came to Kiva in hopes of receiving a new loan for the purchase of an additional DVD player and a quantity of DVDs.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Каримов Сабур является одним из успешных наших клиентов с 2004 года. Он женат и имеет одного сына.Жена домохозайка,помогает его матери по дому. Торговлей он занимается на протяжении 10 лет. Раньше Сабур торговал касетами для аудио аппаратуры на улице. После получения первого займа с Микроинвеста он увеличил объём своей продукции и успешно погасил займ. В дальнейшем он накопил деньги на собственный магазин и сегодня он имеет большой выбор дисков и много постоянных клиентов не только местных потребтителей, но и с отдаленных районов. В Киву он обратился с просьбой на получение займа на покупку дополнительного DVD и закупку новых дисков для записи.

loans.use: Purchase of an additional DVD player and DVDs

loans.name: Chon

texts.en:
Mrs. Chon C. L., 35, and her husband, Mr. He Hal, are rice farmer and fishers. She lives with her family in the village of the Svey Tadork in the province of the Siem Reap in Cambodia. They both earn about $7 a day. She has two children, one of whom is a student. The other is just a young child. Because of her business, she can pay her family’s expenses and pay for her children to go to school. Previously, she successfully concluded a loan with HKL for two cycles.

In order to upgrade her fishing business, L. is now asking for a loan of $1100 to buy fishing tools (nets and trap). She appreciates Kiva and promises to be prompt in repaying her loan.

loans.use: To buy fishing tools (nets and trap) to upgrade her fishing business

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy E. is a strong and energetic woman, she hail from ilogbo, Lagos State, Nigeria. At 30 years of age, with her 3 children, she is focused and determined to enlarge her business. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. Joy has been in this business since 2003 and needs a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more provisions and drinks and foodstuff for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs for sale.

loans.name: Geniphar

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 38 year-old Geniphar K.. She is married, and has four children between the ages of 11 and 18. In 1992, Geniphar established her tailoring business. She earns about US $300 every month from this business. Geniphar requires a loan in order to purchase a sewing machine and 10 dozen pieces of cloth,. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets. The lack of tangible collateral assets means they are deemed not-creditworthy by financial institutions, restricting access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and 10 dozen pieces of cloth.

loans.name: Kikelomo

texts.en:
Kikelomo I. sells yams, sweet potatoes, bananas and plantain in Okoko market. She comes to her shop on Mondays through Saturdays at 7am and stays until night fall, selling her goods to her customers. She is 40 years old and is married with 5 children.

Kikelomo has the ambition to expand her business by buying more yams, sweet potatoes, bananas and plantain with the loan of $700 that she is requesting. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria, close to the market and, with a larger inventory, she will be able to satisfy her customers more fully. She says thanks to Kiva and her lenders.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell.

loans.name: Melanie Epiphanie

texts.fr:
Mrs. Mélanie Epiphanie A. is married to Mr. Honoré Koffi Blam, a photographer, and was born on January 7, 1971 in Lomé. She is raising four children. She has been selling cosmetics and staples since 1996. With a lot of experience in this business, she earns a daily profit that allows her to help her husband cater for family expenses.

This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to purchase a case of perfume.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Mariée à monsieur BLAM Honoré Koffi qui est un photographe, Madame A. Mélanie Epiphanie est née le 07 janvier 1971 à Lomé. Elle a quatre enfants en charge. Elle est revendeuse de produits de beauté et des produits de premières nécessités depuis 1996. Très expérimenté dans cette activité, elle tire son revenu journalier ce qui lui permet d’aider son mari dans les dépenses familiales.

Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter un carton de parfum.

loans.use:
Purchase of cosmetics for re-sale

Achat de produits de beauté

loans.name: Kweku

texts.en: Kweku A. sells drinks at the seashore and his main customers are the fishermen. He is also a fisherman as an extra job. He is married, but his wife's income is not sufficient for Kweku and his 4 children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business.

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Aziza is 30 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 6 and 4 years old. She has been a food seller since 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 4pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Aziza is now looking for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Khoeun N., 41, and his wife, Mrs. Sony Choub, 37, live along National Road Number Six about seventeen Kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1995 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of their children study in the local school.

Mr. Khoeun has been growing vegetables for seven years. He grows many types of vegetables on the farm near his house. Mrs. Sony does farming with her husband and raises pigs at home. Currently, she is creating a new business selling coffee in front of her house but lacks the money to build a shelter to serve her customers. Therefore, Khoeun is requesting a loan of $1000 to build a shelter for his wife to sell coffee and to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy piglets and to build a shelter for selling coffee

loans.name: Yessenia

texts.es:
La señorita Yessenia  pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres de Éxito”, ubicado en el Jr. Emilio Tipto Nº 115 “San Fernando”, distrito de Manantay, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 20 años de edad y es soltera. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300, decide invertir en la venta de productos de belleza “AVON”. Tiene 2 años trabajando con Manuela Ramos.

En la actualidad se está preparando para postular a la Universidad. Cuenta con una motokar como herramienta de trabajo, la cual hace trabajar todos los días para tener otros ingresos económicos.    

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 3 llantas, 5 focos, catalinas, etc., y arreglará el motor.

Yessenia manifiesta que gracias a Manuela Ramos se realizó como mujer y tendrá la oportunidad de estudiar una carrera profesional.
texts.en:
Yessenia belongs to the "Mujeres de Éxito" [Successful Women] communal bank located at Jr. Emilio Tipto Nº 115 “San Fernando”, Manantay district, Coronel Portillo province, Ucayali. She is 20 years old and single. She decided to invested the first loan of 300 soles she received from Manuela Ramos in the sale of AVON beauty products. She has been working with Manuela Ramos for two years.

At present Yessenia is preparing for university application.She has a motokar (a motorcycle with a cart behind it), which she uses every day to raise more income.

She will purchase 3 tyres, wheels, 5 car lights etc and will get the motor fixed using the present loan of 1000 soles . This amount will be paid back in 5 months.

Yessenia demonstrates how she has established herself as a woman and will have the opportunity of a professional education thanks to Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Edit Pecsi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tyres, lights, wheels and repair the motor of the motokar.

loans.name: Nom

texts.en: Mrs. Nom V. was born in 1957 and now lives in Soteap village in the Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. South Phel, are farmers who own a plot of land and cultivate rice to earn a living. This is the only business supporting their family. Thus, Mrs. Nom V. decided to ask for a loan to buy five piglets and feed to start a new breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Nom V. has five children; two of whom are laborers, one is employed in a garment factory and the others attend the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase five piglets and feed to begin a breeding business.

loans.name: Ra

texts.en:
Mrs. Ra M. is a farmer who lives in Boeng Ka Erk Village in Kandal Province. She is a 40-year-old widow with five children. One of her children is employed in the garment factory, another owns a small soup restaurant, and the remaining three attend the local school. 

Although Mrs. Ra M. and her children have many businesses, they still do not have enough money to build a kitchen to cook. To enable Mrs. Ra M. to cook, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy timbers to build a kitchen.

loans.use: To buy timbers to build a kitchen for cooking.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary P. sells clothing and fabrics at Ankaful, near Elmina. Mary has received no formal education.  She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a security man. Mary has been selling clothing and fabrics since 2005. She is responsible for paying rent, utility bills and other financial expenses. Her loan will be used as additional capital to enable her to increase the sale of clothing and fabric and meet the increase in demand by her costumers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into the business, and increase her profit margin so as to meet the financial needs of her large family size.

In the picture are examples of the type of clothing she trades in.

loans.use: To enable her to increase the sale of clothing and fabric and meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Gregoria Bernarda

texts.es: Doña Gregoria tiene 48 años de edad, con dos hijos de 15 y 19 años de edad, que estudian, reside en laureles sur, junto con su esposo trabaja en su negocio que vende mercadería en general en un mercado de la capital de Managua,  desde hace seis años vende, inicio con fondos propios, esta es su quinta solicitud en Afodenic que ha sido de beneficios para invertir en su negocio. Con esta solicitud va a comprar mercadería variada ropa de niño, adultos, chinos de niños, cosméticos   para ofertar  a sus clientes, y la captación de otros, sus objetivos es vender otros productos que generen buenos ingresos a su capital para poder dar estudios a sus hijos y sean unos profesionales.
texts.en:
Gregoria, 48, has two children, 15 and 19, both at school. She lives in the Laureles Sur neighborhood of Managua. With her husband, she's operated a business selling general merchandise in a Managua market for six years. She started the business with her own funds. This is her fifth AFODENIC loan, all of which have been invested in the business. With this loan, Gregoria will buy merchandise, such as clothing and cosmetics, for resale to both her existing customers and any new ones that she can capture. Her goal is to sell different products that will generate the most income so that she, in turn, can educate her children and see them take up professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and cosmetics to resell.

loans.name: Edith Nanfuka Group

texts.en:
Edith is 45 years of age, single, with six children aged between 13 and 23. She rents a one room house where she stays with her children. She has three meals a day and her greatest expense per month is paying tuition fees for her children.

She sells charcoal to earn a living for herself and her family, and she does her business from the market six days a week. She receives about twenty customers a day. Edith has done this kind of business for six years now and so far, she has no challenges. She has been a member of MCDT for four years now and she has so far received eight loans. She has worked with her group for four years and she will use this loan to increase her stock. She also looks forward to expanding her business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Carla

texts.es: Carla tiene 28 años de edad, vive con su esposo y su dos hijos en su casa es propia. Se dedica a la crianza de pollos en un pequeño galpón construido en la parte posterior de su casa, en esta actividad lleva 2 años y le va muy bien, porque no trabaja sola, ya que cuenta con la ayuda de su esposo. Le gusta su trabajo porque a sus pollos los cría con mucho cariño hasta que obtengan el peso necesario para su venta. Este negocio le es rentable porque sus pollos ya están listos para la venta en menos de 45 días y los deja a aun buen precio, aparte de contar ya con fieles clientes. Para el futuro Carla quiere mandar a construir otro galpón porque el que tiene solo le alcanza para 100 pollos y ella está dispuesta a criar más. Su banco comunal se llama “Trabajando juntos”, este es su 7mo préstamo con MFP, nos cuenta que últimamente están habiendo algunos problemas en su grupo, pero tiene la esperanza que puedan solucionarse pronto. Más allá de eso, ella tiene el compromiso de ser responsable en el pago de sus cuotas. El dinero que está solicitando lo invertirá en la compra de pollos bebés y alimentos para los mismos.
texts.en:
Carla is 28 years old and lives with her husband and two children in their own house. She's been raising chickens in a small shed in the rear of the house for two years. The business is going very well because she doesn't work alone: her husband also helps. This business is profitable because her chickens are ready to sell in less than 45 days and she sells them at a good price. She also has loyal customers. In the future, Carla would like to build another shed because the one she has only has room for 100 chickens, and she'd like to raise more. Her communal bank is called "Trabajando juntos" ("Working Together") and this is her seventh loan with MFP. She tells us that recently there have been some problems in her group, but she hopes they can be resolved quickly. Apart from that, she promises to be responsible in making her payments. She will invest the requested loan in purchasing chicks and feed.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chicks and feed to raise poultry

loans.name: Tope

texts.en: Tope is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She sells lumber and hopes to expand this business.  She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more lumber to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more lumber to sell

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Monsieur  K. kokou réside dans le quartier de hedrznawoè, il exerce le métier de réparateur d’appareil électronique, il y a associé le commerce de télévisions qu’il profite pour vendre à ses clients. Le commerce de télévision marche bien pour lui, il voudrait acheter plus de télévision et sollicite donc de WAGES un crédit qui lui permettrai d’acheter 10 télévisions et du matériel pour son travail. Il est marié et a 04 enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. Kokou K. resides in the Hedrznawoè neighborhood and repairs electrical appliances. He also sells TVs to his customers. The sales of TVs are going well for him. He would like to buy more TVs and so is requesting a loan from WAGES which will permit him to buy 10 televisions and some materials for his work. He is married and has 4 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of televisions for re-sale

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita V. is from the village of Salvador. She is 39 years old and married. She owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 11 years.

Perlita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seed, seedlings and young crops to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the pioneer microfinance institutions in the Philippines committed to serve the needy in Central and Northern Luzon through socio-economic development and holistic transformation.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seed, seedlings and young crops

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice A. is a 28-year-old mother of three children. She is married to a businessman who sells second hand belts. She has a small boutique just outside of the main downtown area in Kisumu. She buys her clothing stock from Busia, which is on the border with Uganda. This is her first loan.

In this video, you can hear the interviewer greet Eunice saying "Idhi Nade" -- which is Luo for "How are you?" Eunice responds, "Adhi maber," meaning "very good." Most people living in Kisumu descend from the Luo tribe, the same tribe as Obama's father. At the end, the interviewer fluctuates between Kiswahili and Luo saying "Asante Sana" in Kiswahili, meaning "Thank you," and "Erokamano," which in Luo means "thank you." The voices in the background are coming for a weekly K-MET borrower meeting. To see what one looks like, check out the first video in this blog post: http://fellowsblog.kiva.org/2009/05/14/m-banking/


K-MET, the NGO giving the loan, is unique in that it is not a traditional MFI. Rather, it is a development corporation focused on raising health standards in Kenya. To read more about K-MET’s work, please click here: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=24

loans.use: To purchase clothing stock

loans.name: Sadia

texts.en: Saida J. is 22 years old and is married with a husband who is a farmer. She has four children and her children go to school. Saida is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase more vegetables to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Amparo De La Concepcion

texts.es: Amparo de la Concepción B. tiene 48 años. Es una mujer trabajadora. Amparo trabaja desde muy joven, pues su actividad económica es el destace de cerdo. Ya que es el único oficio que conoce y que le ha generado ganancias. Algunas veces recorre lugares muy lejano por buscar el cerdo que le ofrecen a un buen precio. Amparo tiene los deseos de mejorar su establecimiento pues es aquí donde ofrece sus productos. El dinero que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de cerdos y algunos utensilios.
texts.en:
Amparo de la Concepción B. is a 48-year-old hard-working woman. Amparo has worked since she was very young, and she butchers pigs for a living. This is the only work she knows and it has generated profits for her. Sometimes she travels long distances to find pigs for a good price. She has dreams of improving her location because it is where she sells her products. The money she is requesting is for working capital so she can buy pigs and tools.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn M. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 45 years old, married and has 2 adult children. Marilyn owns & operates a service-based business. Marilyn is just starting this business.

In 2008, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Marilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Los Olivos Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Los Olivos inicia su cuarto ciclo con 21 socias, las socias viven en L. Asociación Los Olivos.
	
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. jugos, abarrotes en general, cosméticos, comida, quesos, joyas, tubérculos, animales menores.
	
Como es el caso D. Odilia que es casada, tiene 57 años y 8 hijos, Odilia tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, bebidas, actividad que realiza con L. ayuda D. sus hijos.
	
Por otro lado Nuria es soltera, tiene 47 años y 4 hijos, Nuria tiene una bodega en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, además por las noches venD. salchipapas en L. puerta D. su tienda. También Nuria venD. jugos en el mercado central para lo cual cuenta con L. ayuda D. su hija.
	 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles  haciendo un total D. 11,850 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en L. compra D. arroz, azúcar, frutas, variadas, aceite, carne, animales, menores, cosméticos.

Los sueños D. las socias son que sus negocios mejoren, sus hijos culminen sus estudios y tener negocios estables.
texts.en:
The Los Olivos communal bank starts its 4th loan cycle with 21 members who live in the Los Olivos association. The members have different businesses such as the sale of juices, groceries, cosmetics, food, cheeses, jewelry, root vegetables and small livestock. For example: Odilia is married, 57 years old and has 8 children. Odilia has a store in her house where she sells basic goods and drinks, which is something she does with the help of her children. Nuria is single, 47 years old and has 4 children. Nuria has a convenience store in her house where she sells basic goods and in addition, at night sells salchipapas (fast-food dish of fried hot dogs and french fries) from the store. Nuria also sells juices in the central market with the help of her daughter. The members need different loan amounts from the communal bank. Their loans will be used to buy rice, sugar, a variety of fruit, oil, meat, small livestock and cosmetics. The members dreams are to improve their businesses and that their children finish their schooling and have stable businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, a variety of fruit, oil, meat, small livestock, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Sixto

texts.es:
El señor Sixto es casado, tiene 54 años de edad, con 5 hijos, de los cuales 1 solo depende de él económicamente.

El montó su despensa hace 9 años, con un pequeño capital que había ahorrado, además de la despensa tiene un ingreso agregado por servicios de fletes en su camión de cargas. 
La jornada de el comienza muy temprano, pues, a las 5 de la mañana está en pie dispuesto a cualquier actividad que se presente. 
Por fortuna tiene el apoyo de todos sus hijos y su esposa por lo que los compromisos asumidos por él pueden cumplir con cabalidad. 
 Su máximo sueño es comprar un camión más grande.

loans.use: Compra de Vinos, Yerbas, Azúcar y Otros

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar L. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband is a lawyer and gives legal advice. He also sometimes works as a legal assistant. Otgonbayar is an English translator who had first worked at her sister's company and then, in 2004, started her own "Double" Co., Ltd translation company.

Her monthly revenues can be as high as 800,000 tugrug (~563 USD) with a net profit of 300,000 tugrug (~210 USD). She is working hard to open a new branch and still struggling to maintain and continue her business. One of the reasons for her success is that she is good at accounting.

One of her most important goals is to educate her children well so that they can lead their own lives without any difficulty. For that reason she is trying hard to increase the company's profit. She says that doing translation work for others is a very helpful thing to do. She states "I am happy to see smiling faces everyday". All of her customers are satisfied with the translation work that her company does for them. They say that they trust the translations done by Otgobayar's employees more than any other translating company.

Otgonbayer would like to purchase new dictionaries, computers and necessary stationary in order to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of her business. She is requesting a 2,600,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan.

loans.use: To purchase office equipment and supplies

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en:
Dominic owns a grocery in the Kwa njenga part of the Mukuru slum in Nairobi. Dominic has requested his first loan of Kes. 50,000 in order to open another outlet after running the current one successfully for eight years. He hopes to one day open multiple locations for his grocery and start exporting fruits.  Married with two children, Dominic also cares for his parents. He describes himself as patient and honest.



About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Open another outlet

loans.name: Israel

texts.es:
Al vivienda del señor Israel B. le está haciendo falta el techo de dos cuartos pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder pagarle a la persona que se encargara de poner el techo ya que lo quiere de concreto para que sea más duradero y seguro para su familia ya que tiene tres hijos pequeños de edad. 
Planea pagar el crédito con los ingresos que obtiene de su empleo como jardinero del municipio, ya que su esposa la señora Luz Del Carmen Hernández se encargara de los gastos familiares con su ingreso que tiene como de su trabaja como veladora de una compañía. 
La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Luz Del Carmen Hernández esposa del señor Israel ya que el se encontraba en su trabaja cuando se realizo la visita.
texts.en:
The home of Mr. Israel Bermudez is missing the roof over the bedrooms. At this time, because he wants it built from concrete so that it will be longer lasting and safer for his family and three young children, he lacks the money necessary to pay the person who will be in charge of putting on the roof. Since his wife Mrs. Luz Del Carmen Hernandez will be taking care of the family expenses with the income from her job as watchperson for a company, he plans on paying this loan with the income from his job as municipal gardener. Because he was at work when the visit was made, the person who appears in the picture is Mrs. Luz Del Carmen Hernandez, wife of Israel.

Translated from Spanish by Joseph Tobin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: placement of concrete tile

loans.name: Jaquelin Sugey

texts.es: La Joven Jacquelin Sugey González tiene la edad de 26 años habita en la comunidad las enramadas, junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como transportista para apoyarle con los gastos del hogar, ellos tienen un hijos a cargo , los planes hacia su familia es poder brindarle un mejor educación y un techo digno , ella desde hace un año trabaja como domestica trabajo en el cual es cansado por que tiene que cocinar, lavar ,planchar a varias persona lo cual lo hace para en un futuro tener su casa mas amplia , anteriormente laboraba como cajera y despachadora de una pulpería pero por las ventas bajas la liquidaron.  La mayor dificultad que se le presenta es que no puede comprar de una solo vez los materiales de construcción, por el sueldo que devenga es bajo y el de su esposo también pues tiene cubrir las necesidades diaria del hogar,  Agradece a Afodenic por la buena aprobación de su segundo préstamo; el cual lo va a invertir en compra de materiales de construcción como: piedra, cemento para ajustar ya que con el primer crédito compro una parte para hacer un cuarto el cual va a terminar de construir para mejor seguridad de su familia.
texts.en:
Jacquelin Sugey González is 26 years old and lives in the community of Las Enramadas. Her husband works as a delivery driver in order to help with the household expenses. The couple has one dependent child. Jacquelin’s plan for her family includes providing a good education for her child as well as a decent home. She has been working as a domestic employee for a year. She easily tires from having to cook, clean, and iron for different people, but she does whatever it takes so that she can have a larger home in the future. Jacquelin previously worked as a cashier and dispatcher at a grocery store before her employer went bankrupt because of low sales.

Her greatest challenge is not being able to purchase all of her construction materials at once because she does not make enough money and her husband’s salary is used to cover their daily household necessities. Jacquelin thanks AFODENIC for approving her second loan. She will use the funds to purchase materials such as stone and cement. Her first loan was used to buy enough materials to finish a room, but she would like to complete the construction of the entire house so that she can provide better security for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase building materials

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en:
Ngozi sells groceries and has been in the business for two years. She has been selling items like tomatoes, bread and milk, but due to the demand for rice and beans, she hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase rice and beans, along with other groceries, in bulk at a discount. This, she said, will enable her to satisfy her customers' needs and increase her capital and profit.

Ngozi is 31 years old and married, and she has three children. She is a hard-working woman, and she works long hours to make more profit in order to meet the basic needs of her family. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans and more groceries in bulk

loans.name: Jeska

texts.en: Jeska S. Myanya, 65, is a remarkable woman who is a role model for her extended family and her borrowing group.  Her husband died young as did three of her children. Jeska she is raising their six remaining children on her own. She quit her job as a cleaning woman for the city council and set out to start a small businesses with her family.  In conjunction with her family members, she has started a mandazie business (a sweet breakfast baked good) for distribution to stalls, a flavored ice business to sell to nearby schools, a fish business, as well as chipatis, cooked beans and sambeesas (a snack) to sell to food stalls and restaurants. She will use this loan to start a new enterprise.  She will purchase processed coal cheaply from a factory near Tanzania to sell locally. She would like her grandchildren to be educated. They manage their small businesses with her and while never missing school.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal cheaply from a factory to sell locally

loans.name: Isidora

texts.es:
La señora ISIDORA C. J. tiene 53 años, vive en el distrito deL PORVENIR, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal CARIDAD II. La socia presenta estudios  hasta 5to de primaria, refiere que es de la sierra y que desde pequeña se dedicó a trabajar, por ese motivo no continuó sus estudios; es conviviente  y tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen económicamente de ella. La socia se dedica a la crianza de pollos para su posterior comercialización, también se dedica a la confeccion de ropa para caballeros, damas y niños.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles, compró pollos bebes los cuales vendió.
Con este crédito de 500.00 nuevos soles, comprará pollos y alimento balanceado al por mayor. Ella sueña con aumentar la crianza de sus pollos.
texts.en:
Miss ISIDORA C. J. is 53 years old, she lives in the EL PORVENIR district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department in Peru. She belongs to the Communal Bank CARIDAD II. The member has a 5th grade primary school education, she is from the mountain and since she was little she started working, which is why she didn't finish studying. Isidora is cohabiting and has 5 children, 2 of whom are still economically dependent. This member is dedicated to raising chickens and manufacturing clothing for gentlemen, ladies and kids. With her first credit of 300.00 new soles, she purchased baby chickens whom she sold. With this credit of 500.00 new soles she will purchase chickens and wholesale chicken food. She dreams of increase her chicken raising.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE CHICKENS AND WHOLESALE CHICKEN FOOD

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 51-year-old married man and the father of one child who is at university. He has owned a pastry shop since 2004 from which he provides delicious sweet products to customers in his town and the neighboring villages. Today, Hasan is requesting to borrow $1,000 USD to buy a shop window to present his products and attract more customers.

loans.use: To buy a shop window to present his products

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou D. est âgée de 53 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WALIDANE depuis 3 ans. Elle fait de la teinture et vend des parfums. Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie et de renforcer son niveau d'épargne.
texts.en:
Fatou D. is a 53-year-old married mother of 6 children. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" (Village loan group) of Walidane for 3 years. She dyes clothing and sells perfume. Her goal is to participate in improving her living conditions and to increase the level of her savings.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen and develop her commercial activity

loans.name: Rosita's Group

texts.en:
Rosita F. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 60 years old. Rosita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Rosita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sron

texts.en: Mr. Sron L. lives in Doung Khpos village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of loan to grow rice to earn a living. He is also a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Bun Vany, is a farmer. Although they try to work very hard, they still don't earn enough income to support the family. Thus, Mr. Sron L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a plowing machine to plow the villagers’ rice fields for income. Mr. Sron L. is a father of a child who too young to work or study. His wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a plowing machine

loans.name: El Trio Group

texts.es:
El Trio es un grupo muy unido conformado por personas trabajadoras una de ellas es la señora Gloria Genoveva S. Mejía quien vende productos de la Avon marca reconocida en Nicaragua. Estos productos tienen mucha demanda por  la  población.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Mayra del Socorro García quien tiene un puesto de recargas telefónicas y Gema Iveth U. S. vende tortillas. Ellas invertirán el crédito en sus negocios para mejorarlos y fortalecerlos.
texts.en:
El Trio is a very united group made up of hard working people. One of them is Mrs Gloria Genoveva S. Mejía who sells Avon products, a brand that is well known in Nicaragua. These products are in great demand by the population. Her fellow group members are Mayra del Socorro García, who has a stand for recharging telephones, and Gema Iveth U. S. who sells tortillas. They will invest their loans in their businesses to make improvements and strengthen them.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To by cosmetics.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen, 49, has 1-hectare rice field and a sari-sari store. Aside from that, she also raises pigs. At first, she borrowed money from other dealers to have capital but she only profits very little because of high interest. When Community Economic Ventures, Inc. came, it made it easier for her to secure additional capital and her business is progressing.

She is currently requesting a loan of 15,000 Php. This will allow her to buy farm supplies and groceries. She works as much as she can to support her family and her 3 children.

loans.use: farm supplies and groceries to sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Mrs. Norma L. is from Molave Zamboanga del Sur. She is 60 years old, widowed, with 2 children. To make living she operates her sari-sari store to have an income. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes primarily from her farm. She has operated her business for more than 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 a month.

She joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid her previous loan of 7,000 taken from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Norma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 which will be used to purchase additional items to be sold. This will be her 4th cycle of loans from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice S. is from the village of Salvacion, Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 51 years old. Alice is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Alice owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of different products in the local community. Alice has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alice joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Alice has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & towards working capital. Alice is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Alice from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn T. is a 50-year-old mother blessed with four children, two of whom have already married and started new homes, while the other two are single. She has a daughter who is working as a tailor in the garment industry. Sorn owns a medium-sized piece of farmland upon which she and her husband (shown on the right in the photo) plant rice crops to earn a living.

Sorn lacks some supplies to support her farming business and so has requested a loan of $400 to buy fertilizer and seed, with any remaining money to be used for house repairs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seed to grow.

loans.name: Khardiata

texts.fr:
Madame Khardiata T. est une femme mariée âgée de 35 ans. Elle est mère de deux enfants âgés respectivement de 11 ans et 2 ans. Cette dame est une handicapée et se déplace sur une chaise roulante.  C'est en 2003 qu'elle s'est investie dans le commerce car d'après elle, la mendicité ne suffit pas pour subvenir à ses besoins. Elle vend cependant des tissus, encens et tous autres types de produits qui sont à bon marché et aimés par les clients. Elle est à sa première demande de crédit et compte s'approvisionner en produits.
Ainsi elle pourra avec ce business augmenter et diversifier leur revenu car son mari hancicapé aussi compte sur la mendicité pour nourir sa famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Khardiata T. is a married woman who is 35 years old. She is mother to two children, aged 11 and two years old respectively. This lady is disabled and moves around in a wheelchair. In 2003 she set herself up in business, since she considers that begging is not sufficient to provide for her needs. She thus sells fabrics, incense and all other types of products that are cheap and appreciated by her customers. This is the first time she has asked for a loan and she plans to stock up on products. As such, she will be able to increase and diversify her business with this income; her disabled husband also counts on begging to feed his family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock up on fabrics and other diverse products

loans.name: Chou

texts.en: A mother of four teenaged children who are employed at various jobs, Mrs. Chou M. has spent her life cultivating crops, a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young.  Chou M. has had great success growing crops, planting at least twice a year by following both the rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall will be good for growing, but she needs a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting.  Her husband earns a living by selling chickens around the community.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, a pump machine, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.es: Alexander N. C., tiene la edad de 33 años, está casado, y tiene 1 hijo que es su mayor prioridad. El tiene 7 años de edad. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de materiales para realizar una cerca eléctrica. Con esta cerca lo que busca es proteger a los animales, de tenerlos más seguros en el potrero.   También desea aumentar el número de animales y poder mantenerlos en mejores condiciones, cuenta con un área idónea para el mantenimiento y cría del ganado. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Alexander  tiene varios años dedicada al ganado. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.
texts.en:
Alexander N. C. is 33 years old and married. He has a seven year old child who is his greatest priority. He wants the loan to buy materials to build an electrical fence. The fence is to protect the animals and have them be more secure in the pasture. He also wishes to increase the number of animals he has and be able to maintain them in better conditions. He has an ideal area in which to maintain and raise the livestock. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR, and he is very happy with the terms of the loan. Alexander has worked with livestock for several years. In the future he hopes to give his family a better quality of life and greater economic security. He also hopes to be able to keep growing as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to build an electrical fence

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia L. is from the town of Talibon. She is 49 years old. Lucia is married. To make a living, Lucia operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling clay products, like pots and vases, to local businesses and community members. Lucia has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Lucia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the first loan taken out by Lucia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and improve their living conditions. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Temur

texts.en:
Temur K. is 41 years old and married with three children. Together with his wife, Temur sells fabric for making the national dresses. Their store is located in the central local market. Temur has been in this business already for 18 years. In order to offer a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet, Temur travels almost every month to the neighboring town to purchase the new goods. During his business absence Temur’s wife helps him in the market with selling. Temur has managed to increase his clientele but he is not able to fully meet the demand, therefore he requests a loan of 6000 Somoni so he can increase his stock. He hopes to earn more income so he can provide his children with a good education and with the best future. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more fabric for his shop.

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion A. is from the village of Rizal, Quirino. She is 57 years old. Visitacion is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Visitacion owns and operates a specialized retail store, where she sells vegetables and meat in the local community. Visitacion has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

Visitacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Visitacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Visitacion is requesting another loan of 9,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Visitacion's fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Say's Group

texts.en:
In Sam Raong village in Takeo province these five people make up a village bank loan. Mrs. S. Y., who was born in 1954, is the village bank president having been selected by the other members. Each member will use their portion of the loan to improve their business.

Mrs. S. Y. and her husband, Mr. Roem Phoeurn, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) plot of land that they use to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Their problem is that their field has infertile soil, but they do not have enough money to solve the problem. So, to improve production, Mrs. S. Y. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer.

Mrs. S. Y. is the mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, another does telephone repair, and the other is a laborer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn T. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. 4, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: Videoke rental, coconut shell sales and fish vending. Her husband Jenises, who is 31 years old, works as a Security Guard to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 3 children who are 8 to 10 years old.

Jenelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jenelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 8000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 5000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan cycle, she is borrowing 15000 PHP, with which she intends to purchase one more videoke machine. This will increase her income and she will continue to save up for the future improvement of their house and the education of their children. Jenelyn T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase New Equipment

loans.name: Bebilyn

texts.en:
Bebilyn M. is a married woman who lives in Purok Wayang, Barangay Patic, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: vegetable sales and fish vending. Her husband Rolly, 47 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 3 children, 9 to 15 years old. Bebilyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Bebilyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 5th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use to buy more stock of vegetables and fertilizer so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Bebilyn M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF  :In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Svay R., 45 years old, owns a small shop located in front of her house where she sells coffee. She typically makes around US$ 3 in profit each day to support her family. Svay R. has been married for many years to Mr. Nou Kan, 59, a local farmer, and they now have two school-aged children, one of whom attends university while the other one attends a high school.

Svay R., is running her business smoothly because she has skills in public relations which she uses with her customers. Currently, she wants to earn more extra income by feeding a few pigs around her house, but she doesn’t have cash to make that possible. Therefore, Svay R. is requesting a loan to purchase pigs to fatten to add more profit.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to fatten

loans.name: Carlos Andres

texts.es:
Carlos Andres tiene 46 años, es casado, tiene un hijo, vive en la ciudad hermosa del Cusco, Perú y desde hace mucho tiempo que participa en el banco comunal “Patrón de San Sebastián” de la Unidad de Micro finanzas Arariwa. Carlos Andres es un padre trabajador y emprendedor que trabaja en el Hotel “Andre” y desempeña el cargo de administrador.
     
Carlos Andres con su próximo préstamo que espera recibir de $ 250 USD, él invertirá para uso personal  y no especifico para que exactamente. 

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Carlos Andres is 46 years old, married, and has a son. He lives in the beautiful city of Cusco, and has for some time participated in the “Patron de San Sebastian” communal bank of the Arariwa Micro-finance Unit.  Carlos Andres is a hard-working and enterprising father who works in the Hotel Andre as its administrator.

For his new loan, Carlos Andres expects to receive $250 U.S. dollars, to be used for unspecified personal needs.

Carlos Andres is grateful for the opportunity offered through this means and also, he promises to comply with all corresponding payments on schedule.

loans.use: FOR HIS PERSONAL NEEDS

loans.name: Sanam

texts.en:
This is 39-year-old Sanam K.. She is married and has five children, aged 19, 18, 16, 14 and 11. In 2000, she established her dairy business. Working seven days a week and five hours a day, she supoorts her family. She has already received and successfully repaid two loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to purchase a young dairy cow.  

In the future, Sanam plans to improve the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about ten liters of milk each day. In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50.  

In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women (Patan BPW). Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. It operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.
